review_title: Meaningful mission but there is tremendous room for growth as an organization
pros:
- Meaningful mission, beautiful work that is being done for every nation and language
- Great, hardworking people
- Great work space / modern office landscape (coffee bar, cafeteria, ping-pong table, private conference rooms, etc.)
- Up-to-date technologies to be able to do your job well. Willing to pay for other technologies to do better
- Flexible, generous holiday / PTO schedule
- Amazing benefits
- 9/80 work schedule and remote work available
- Christian values throughout the organization
- Employee engagement events like all-inclusive yearly staff retreat (pre-covid)
- New CEO is very adamant about helping to foster change within the organization and continue to push Seed Company where God has called it. I am very hopeful that the following cons are currently being worked on.
cons:
- Salary ranges are below industry standard
- Leadership fails to communicate preemptively. "Fires" are an unfortunate all-too-common communication style
- Performance management processes help encourage individual goals but there are no growth opportunities that stem from them
- Room to grow as an employee is extremely limited, promotions are more or less based on being in "the right place at the right time"
- Salary raises are rare, outside of a very small "affirmation" at the end of each year, amounting to 1-3% of salary
- Silos exist between departments / teams making it difficult to understand where and what each team is doing, and overlap of work is recurring.
- Team structure / business objectives change almost seasonally. This makes it difficult to understand and clearly identify where we were headed as an organization
- Employee turnover is high within the last 2-3 years
- Diversity & Inclusion is an unfortunate situation within the company. To speak as respectfully towards the subject and company as I can: you will find very few people of color within the general staff, within the executive team, and within the board of directors.

pros:
Its obvious that almost everyone there has a heart to serve.

The mission is  amazing.

Seed Company is very well funded compared to most missions organizations, so you probably will have the tools necessary to do your job well.
cons:
Have moved too far toward "business best practices."  As a result, there has been outsourcing, cutbacks, and, based on feedback from those who preceded and followed me in leaving, a decrease in connection to the purpose.

Honest feedback is getting rarer.  Even well-handled criticism of leadership ideas/initiatives is perceived as risky.  Many folks have left after well-reasoned feedback was provided and they subsequently felt unwelcome, had their performance criticized, and their motives questioned.

pros: It was a decent place to springboard my career into IT, I suppose. Equipment choice was pretty decent, being a mixed PC/Mac shop. I LOVED most of my users and people I had to help. On the other hand...
cons: Leadership across the board is full of ideators and no doers. Everyone can see it from 70,000 feet up, but nobody wants to get down and dirty with ideas it seems. 100% leadership turnover or close to it in the last year and a half, and every few months they need to reorganize this department yet again. Lots of bosses, but few leaders most of the time. Middle managers won't stick up for you when impossible deadlines have been set, and once that's done, you might as well pack up and leave, because it's all on you. Time spent there means nothing, what you've done in the past means nothing, if someone thinks that you're the one that deserves to be under that bus when the project is over. Core values go out the window at that point. Many have left, some have been shown the door, or pushed through it. No training, no room for growth, etc.

pros:
Seed Company is one-of-a-kind in a lot of ways. Its organizational structure, culture, and processes are more innovative than most organizations. 

The organization has an inspiring mission, Fantastic atmosphere, and a great work-life balance. Opportunities to travel internationally for some positions exist and is encouraged. There is an openness to process improvement. Management and executives are approachable and open to input. Organization challenges itself to do better and not accept the status quo.

Seed Company is in the midst of really exceptional growth both in its business units and specifically in Technology or products it offers. So, if you want to have a chance to shape/disrupt the landscape of Bible Translation through innovation, this is the place for you.
cons:
Seed Company's newly forming culture isn't for everyone. All knowledge is silo-ed and tribal, which means the environment is very collaborative with a startup mentality or feel. 

Seed Company is also a *fast-paced* place to work for many teams. If you're working on a team that's *really* getting things done, don't be surprised if you work as hard as or harder than you've ever done in your life. While the age-old adage, work hard play hard is correct here, the work is *really valuable* and rewarding, because of the life transformation that organization is bringing to billions of people through God's word.

pros: A growing organization with a meaningful mission.

Some of the best reasons to work at Seed Company:
- They are truly interested in their employees at a personal level. 
- The pace is slower, but that also means more intentional.
- The compensation is wonderful and fair for a non-profit.
- Their benefits and PTO are some of the best I've seen in many fields.
- The training is great, and if you miss a step, your supervisor is ready to help guide you. It's a gracious environment.
cons:
The only con I can think of is that you have to want to be a part of the environment, but you'll be blessed for it! If you miss out on prayer times, devotionals, team building activities, it will (of course) hold you back from being a part of the team. If you want to come in to work, put your head down, and be left alone, this is not the place for you. 

If you lose steam for the mission of the company, it is really obvious and it becomes a big hindrance in being full invested in what's happening here.

pros: Being in a Christian organization with a huge emphasis on prayer is actually pretty refreshing when you start. Steady schedule is amazing and the pay was decent for starting my career.
cons: Leadership across the board has no idea how to execute ideas. 100% executive team turn over in the last 18 months which has caused several teams to be reorganized multiple times. I had to endure 5 bosses in 4 years and some for just a few weeks at a time! My job description was constantly being changed. Lower level managers allowed unrealistic deadlines to be made and then punished the underlings when things went wrong. Several long time staff members have left or been shown the door or became so frustrated that they quit. This is the most apparent in I.T. where grand ideas about apps are discussed and then never released or the app is so force fed to the staff they refuse to use it even in beta.

review_title: The best place I've worked and also the most demanding.
pros: In 2020, there has been a seismic shift to get back to basics and focus on what's important. This renewed focus has helped unify teams and the organization through enhanced partnerships. There is an incredible commitment to the mission at every level of the organization. People, for the most part, are authentic, like-minded spiritually, and others-focused. As an employee, I feel cared for and supported by not only my leadership but our organizational leadership.
cons: When the vision is compelling like Seed Company's and the task so large, it's hard to focus on the most critical work that generates the most progress. At times, this leads to unsustainable commitment because of the innovative streak in the organizational DNA. While exiting, it creates a fast past, demanding environment which could be chaotic for some because of frequent changes.

pros: The mission of Bible Translation is very fulfilling. Seed Company has a strong culture of prayer and many people are compassionate, concerned individuals. I have made many close friends.
cons: Seed Company is in decline. They continue to suffer from poor leadership at the highest level. What was once a groundbreaking, "out of the box" mission is slipping into a competitive and hostile work environment.  As the teams within Seed continue to fracture and mid-level managers compete to gain territory and influence, the vision and scope of the mission is deteriorating. Upper management does not seem to be concerned with team unity or turnover...and there has been a lot of turnover lately.

review_title: Great people, meaningful mission, but mixed up priorities.
pros:
Your peers are typically fun to work with, are positive, and very encouraging. 
You get to pray at work with your coworkers. 
The work can be a lot of fun. 
This job will grow you as an individual. 
Typically you have a sizable budget to work with in order to do your job well (which is not common in the ministry space.)
A good amount of vacation days. 
Health insurance is not bad.
cons:
The CEO leads with an Eastern culture lens which can be difficult to understand or to work under given our western culture lens. (I would google honor v shame and guilt v innocence before working here since they won’t take the time to explain that to you.)
Senior leadership are often removed from the lay people. Don’t expect a lot of contact or clear vision from them. You’ll have to rely on your directors but even sometimes they don’t understand the vision either. 
Repentance is on short supply. It seems that asking for forgiveness represents failure and often this type of environment causes hostility and lack of transparency amongst the leaders and lay people. 
In order to gain clarity, you have to be intentional with pursuing it. It will not come on its own.
Most channels for feedback from lay people to senior leadership have been severed. 
Typically you will not have a growth plan. Often the job you sign up for will be the one you’re stuck with until you leave or switch departments completely within the org. 
Extremely high turnover due to the things mentioned.

pros: The organization has experienced incredible growth over the last several years...with growth comes change. I am encouraged by the changes that are taking place. To reach Vision 2025, where every people group will have a Bible translation project in progress - translation work in general must be accelerated. Ways of working will need to change...change is not easy, but necessary. I applaud the organization for making hard changes.
cons: The organization should work to improve communication to global/remote staff.

review_title: A great mission is now just a business
pros: At its best, Seed Company has a great mission and strong field methodology.  It is also exceptional at fund-raising.  Salaries are about halfway between typical faith-based 501(c)3 and the secular marketplace.
cons:
In 2 years, the tech division had > 75% turnover and I went through 6 reorgs.  :-(  Other teams have had turnover almost as bad.  Person after person who falls out of favor with leadership is reassigned dead-end roles unrelated to their experience or training, until they quit.  This happened over and over again.

The last person in senior leadership with serious BT experience was recently sidelined.  SC is now basically two orgs.  Field & Finance are still doing what they've always done but with ever-increasing turnover and discouragement.  The rest of the organization is a business focused on the primary customer.

If you interview, be sure to ask, "Who is the organization's primary customer?"  It's not unreached peoples, the local Church, or any other group typical to missions.  Most focus is around marketing investment opportunities to the primary customer.

The CIO is over software development, other tech, project management, business analysis, user experience, creatives, videography, writers, and communications; he is also deeply involved in fund-raising.  He isn't a detail person, is usually out of the office, and brags that he doesn't read email.  Hint: If he tells you something, get it in writing.
